004import squidpony.LZSPlus;
005import squidpony.annotation.Beta;
006import squidpony.squidmath.*;
007import squidpony.squidmath.Noise.Noise2D;

014/**
015 * Can be used to generate world maps with a wide variety of data, starting with height, temperature and moisture.
016 * From there, you can determine biome information in as much detail as your game needs, with default implementations
017 * available; one assigns a single biome to each cell based on heat/moisture, and the other gives a gradient between two
018 * biome types for every cell. The maps this produces with {@link SphereMap} are valid for spherical world projections,
019 * while the maps from {@link TilingMap} are for toroidal world projections and will wrap from edge to opposite edge
020 * seamlessly thanks to <a href="https://www.gamedev.net/blog/33/entry-2138456-seamless-noise/">a technique from the
021 * Accidental Noise Library</a> that involves getting a 2D slice of 4D Simplex noise. Because of how Simplex noise
022 * works, this also allows extremely high zoom levels for all types of map as long as certain parameters are within
023 * reason. Other world maps produce more conventional shapes, like {@link SpaceViewMap} and {@link RotatingSpaceMap}
024 * make a view of a marble-like world from space, and others make more unconventional shapes, like {@link EllipticalMap}
025 * or {@link EllipticalHammerMap}, which form a 2:1 ellipse shape that accurately keeps sizes but not relative shapes,
026 * {@link RoundSideMap}, which forms a pill-shape, and {@link HyperellipticalMap}, which takes parameters so it can fit
027 * any shape between a circle or ellipse and a rectangle (the default is a slightly squared-off ellipse). You can access
028 * the height map with the {@link #heightData} field, the heat map with the {@link #heatData} field, the moisture map
029 * with the {@link #moistureData} field, and a special map that stores ints representing the codes for various ranges of
030 * elevation (0 to 8 inclusive, with 0 the deepest ocean and 8 the highest mountains) with {@link #heightCodeData}. The
031 * last map should be noted as being the simplest way to find what is land and what is water; any height code 4 or
032 * greater is land, and any height code 3 or less is water.
033 * <br>
034 * Biome mapping is likely to need customization per-game, but some good starting points are {@link SimpleBiomeMapper},
035 * which stores one biome per cell, and {@link DetailedBiomeMapper}, which gives each cell a midway value between two
036 * biomes.
037 */
038@Beta
039public abstract class WorldMapGenerator implements Serializable {
040    private static final long serialVersionUID = 1L;
041    public final int width, height;
042    public int seedA, seedB, cacheA, cacheB;
043    public GWTRNG rng;
044    public final double[][] heightData, heatData, moistureData;
045    public final GreasedRegion landData;
046    public final int[][] heightCodeData;
047    public double landModifier = -1.0, heatModifier = 1.0,
048            minHeight = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY, maxHeight = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY,
049            minHeightActual = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY, maxHeightActual = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY,
050            minHeat = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY, maxHeat = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY,
051            minWet = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY, maxWet = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY;
052    protected double centerLongitude = 0.0;
053
054    public int zoom = 0, startX = 0, startY = 0, usedWidth, usedHeight;
055    protected IntVLA startCacheX = new IntVLA(8), startCacheY = new IntVLA(8);
056    protected int zoomStartX = 0, zoomStartY = 0;
057    
058    public static final FastNoise DEFAULT_NOISE = new FastNoise(0x1337CAFE, 1f, FastNoise.SIMPLEX, 1);
059
060    /**
061     * Used to implement most of the copy constructor for subclasses; this cannot copy Noise implementations and leaves
062     * that up to the subclass, but will copy all non-static fields defined in WorldMapGenerator from other.
063     * @param other a WorldMapGenerator (subclass) to copy fields from
064     */
065    protected WorldMapGenerator(WorldMapGenerator other) {
066        width = other.width;
067        height = other.height;
068        usedWidth = other.usedWidth;
069        usedHeight = other.usedHeight;
070        landModifier = other.landModifier;
071        heatModifier = other.heatModifier;
072        minHeat = other.minHeat;
073        maxHeat = other.maxHeat;
074        minHeight = other.minHeight;
075        maxHeight = other.maxHeight;
076        minHeightActual = other.minHeightActual;
077        maxHeightActual = other.maxHeightActual;
078        minWet = other.minWet;
079        maxWet = other.maxWet;
080        centerLongitude = other.centerLongitude;
081        zoom = other.zoom;
082        startX = other.startX;
083        startY = other.startY;
084        startCacheX.addAll(other.startCacheX);
085        startCacheY.addAll(other.startCacheY);
086        zoomStartX = other.zoomStartX;
087        zoomStartY = other.zoomStartY;
088        seedA = other.seedA;
089        seedB = other.seedB;
090        cacheA = other.cacheA;
091        cacheB = other.cacheB;
092        rng = other.rng.copy();
093        heightData = ArrayTools.copy(other.heightData);
094        heatData = ArrayTools.copy(other.heatData);
095        moistureData = ArrayTools.copy(other.moistureData);
096        landData = other.landData.copy();
097        heightCodeData = ArrayTools.copy(other.heightCodeData);
098    }
099
100    /**
101     * Gets the longitude line the map is centered on, which should usually be between 0 and 2 * PI.
102     * @return the longitude line the map is centered on, in radians from 0 to 2 * PI
103     */
104    public double getCenterLongitude() {
105        return centerLongitude;
106    }
107
108    /**
109     * Sets the center longitude line to a longitude measured in radians, from 0 to 2 * PI. Positive arguments will be
110     * corrected with modulo, but negative ones may not always act as expected, and are strongly discouraged.
111     * @param centerLongitude the longitude to center the map projection on, from 0 to 2 * PI (can be any non-negative double).
112     */
113    public void setCenterLongitude(double centerLongitude) {
114        this.centerLongitude = centerLongitude % 6.283185307179586;
115    }
116
117    public static final double
118            deepWaterLower = -1.0, deepWaterUpper = -0.7,        // 0
119            mediumWaterLower = -0.7, mediumWaterUpper = -0.3,    // 1
120            shallowWaterLower = -0.3, shallowWaterUpper = -0.1,  // 2
121            coastalWaterLower = -0.1, coastalWaterUpper = 0.02,   // 3
122            sandLower = 0.02, sandUpper = 0.12,                   // 4
123            grassLower = 0.14, grassUpper = 0.35,                // 5
124            forestLower = 0.35, forestUpper = 0.6,               // 6
125            rockLower = 0.6, rockUpper = 0.8,                    // 7
126            snowLower = 0.8, snowUpper = 1.0;                    // 8
127
128    protected static double removeExcess(double radians)
129    {
130        radians *= 0.6366197723675814;
131        final int floor = (radians >= 0.0 ? (int) radians : (int) radians - 1);
132        return (radians - (floor & -2) - ((floor & 1) << 1)) * (Math.PI);
133//        if(radians < -Math.PI || radians > Math.PI)
134//            System.out.println("UH OH, radians produced: " + radians);
135//        if(Math.random() < 0.00001)
136//            System.out.println(radians);
137//        return radians;
138
139    }
140    /**
141     * Constructs a WorldMapGenerator (this class is abstract, so you should typically call this from a subclass or as
142     * part of an anonymous class that implements {@link #regenerate(int, int, int, int, double, double, int, int)}).
143     * Always makes a 256x256 map. If you were using {@link WorldMapGenerator#WorldMapGenerator(long, int, int)}, then
144     * this would be the same as passing the parameters {@code 0x1337BABE1337D00DL, 256, 256}.
145     */
146    protected WorldMapGenerator()
147    {
148        this(0x1337BABE1337D00DL, 256, 256);
149    }
150    /**
151     * Constructs a WorldMapGenerator (this class is abstract, so you should typically call this from a subclass or as
152     * part of an anonymous class that implements {@link #regenerate(int, int, int, int, double, double, int, int)}).
153     * Takes only the width/height of the map. The initial seed is set to the same large long
154     * every time, and it's likely that you would set the seed when you call {@link #generate(long)}. The width and
155     * height of the map cannot be changed after the fact, but you can zoom in.
156     *
157     * @param mapWidth the width of the map(s) to generate; cannot be changed later
158     * @param mapHeight the height of the map(s) to generate; cannot be changed later
159     */
160    protected WorldMapGenerator(int mapWidth, int mapHeight)
161    {
162        this(0x1337BABE1337D00DL, mapWidth, mapHeight);
163    }
164    /**
165     * Constructs a WorldMapGenerator (this class is abstract, so you should typically call this from a subclass or as
166     * part of an anonymous class that implements {@link #regenerate(int, int, int, int, double, double, int, int)}).
167     * Takes an initial seed and the width/height of the map. The {@code initialSeed}
168     * parameter may or may not be used, since you can specify the seed to use when you call {@link #generate(long)}.
169     * The width and height of the map cannot be changed after the fact, but you can zoom in.
170     *
171     * @param initialSeed the seed for the GWTRNG this uses; this may also be set per-call to generate
172     * @param mapWidth the width of the map(s) to generate; cannot be changed later
173     * @param mapHeight the height of the map(s) to generate; cannot be changed later
174     */
175    protected WorldMapGenerator(long initialSeed, int mapWidth, int mapHeight)
176    {
177        width = mapWidth;
178        height = mapHeight;
179        usedWidth = width;
180        usedHeight = height;
181        seedA = (int) (initialSeed & 0xFFFFFFFFL);
182        seedB = (int) (initialSeed >>> 32);
183        cacheA = ~seedA;
184        cacheB = ~seedB;
185        rng = new GWTRNG(seedA, seedB);
186        heightData = new double[width][height];
187        heatData = new double[width][height];
188        moistureData = new double[width][height];
189        landData = new GreasedRegion(width, height);
190        heightCodeData = new int[width][height];
191
192//        riverData = new GreasedRegion(width, height);
193//        lakeData = new GreasedRegion(width, height);
194//        partialRiverData = new GreasedRegion(width, height);
195//        partialLakeData = new GreasedRegion(width, height);
196//        workingData = new GreasedRegion(width, height);
197    }
198
199    /**
200     * Generates a world using a random RNG state and all parameters randomized.
201     * The worlds this produces will always have width and height as specified in the constructor (default 256x256).
202     * You can call {@link #zoomIn(int, int, int)} to double the resolution and center on the specified area, but the width
203     * and height of the 2D arrays this changed, such as {@link #heightData} and {@link #moistureData} will be the same.
204     */
205    public void generate()
206    {
207        generate(rng.nextLong());
208    }
209
210    /**
211     * Generates a world using the specified RNG state as a long. Other parameters will be randomized, using the same
212     * RNG state to start with.
213     * The worlds this produces will always have width and height as specified in the constructor (default 256x256).
214     * You can call {@link #zoomIn(int, int, int)} to double the resolution and center on the specified area, but the width
215     * and height of the 2D arrays this changed, such as {@link #heightData} and {@link #moistureData} will be the same.
216     * @param state the state to give this generator's RNG; if the same as the last call, this will reuse data
217     */
218    public void generate(long state) {
219        generate(-1.0, -1.0, state);
220    }
221
222    /**
223     * Generates a world using the specified RNG state as a long, with specific land and heat modifiers that affect
224     * the land-water ratio and the average temperature, respectively.
225     * The worlds this produces will always have width and height as specified in the constructor (default 256x256).
226     * You can call {@link #zoomIn(int, int, int)} to double the resolution and center on the specified area, but the width
227     * and height of the 2D arrays this changed, such as {@link #heightData} and {@link #moistureData} will be the same.
228     * @param landMod 1.0 is Earth-like, less than 1 is more-water, more than 1 is more-land; a random value will be used if this is negative
229     * @param heatMod 1.125 is Earth-like, less than 1 is cooler, more than 1 is hotter; a random value will be used if this is negative
230     * @param state the state to give this generator's RNG; if the same as the last call, this will reuse data
231     */
232    public void generate(double landMod, double heatMod, long state)
233    {
234        if(cacheA != (int) (state & 0xFFFFFFFFL) || cacheB != (int) (state >>> 32) ||
235                landMod != landModifier || heatMod != heatModifier)
236        {
237            seedA = (int) (state & 0xFFFFFFFFL);
238            seedB = (int) (state >>> 32);
239            zoom = 0;
240            startCacheX.clear();
241            startCacheY.clear();
242            startCacheX.add(0);
243            startCacheY.add(0);
244            zoomStartX = width >> 1;
245            zoomStartY = height >> 1;
246
247        }
248        //System.out.printf("generate, zoomStartX: %d, zoomStartY: %d\n", zoomStartX, zoomStartY);
249
250        regenerate(startX = (zoomStartX >> zoom) - (width >> 1 + zoom), startY = (zoomStartY >> zoom) - (height >> 1 + zoom),
251                //startCacheX.peek(), startCacheY.peek(),
252                usedWidth = (width >> zoom), usedHeight = (height >> zoom), landMod, heatMod, seedA, seedB);
253    }
254
255    /**
256     * Halves the resolution of the map and doubles the area it covers; the 2D arrays this uses keep their sizes. This
257     * version of zoomOut always zooms out from the center of the currently used area.
258     * <br>
259     * Only has an effect if you have previously zoomed in using {@link #zoomIn(int, int, int)} or its overload.
260     */
261    public void zoomOut()
262    {
263        zoomOut(1, width >> 1, height >> 1);
264    }
265    /**
266     * Halves the resolution of the map and doubles the area it covers repeatedly, halving {@code zoomAmount} times; the
267     * 2D arrays this uses keep their sizes. This version of zoomOut allows you to specify where the zoom should be
268     * centered, using the current coordinates (if the map size is 256x256, then coordinates should be between 0 and
269     * 255, and will refer to the currently used area and not necessarily the full world size).
270     * <br>
271     * Only has an effect if you have previously zoomed in using {@link #zoomIn(int, int, int)} or its overload.
272     * @param zoomCenterX the center X position to zoom out from; if too close to an edge, this will stop moving before it would extend past an edge
273     * @param zoomCenterY the center Y position to zoom out from; if too close to an edge, this will stop moving before it would extend past an edge
274     */
275    public void zoomOut(int zoomAmount, int zoomCenterX, int zoomCenterY)
276    {
277        zoomAmount = Math.min(zoom, zoomAmount);
278        if(zoomAmount == 0) return;
279        if(zoomAmount < 0) {
280            zoomIn(-zoomAmount, zoomCenterX, zoomCenterY);
281            return;
282        }
283        if(zoom > 0)
284        {
285            if(cacheA != seedA || cacheB != seedB)
286            {
287                generate(rng.nextLong());
288            }
289            zoomStartX = Math.min(Math.max(
290                    (zoomStartX + (zoomCenterX - (width >> 1))) >> zoomAmount,
291                    width >> 1), (width << zoom - zoomAmount) - (width >> 1));
292            zoomStartY = Math.min(Math.max(
293                    (zoomStartY + (zoomCenterY - (height >> 1))) >> zoomAmount,
294                    height >> 1), (height << zoom - zoomAmount) - (height >> 1));
295//            System.out.printf("zoomOut, zoomStartX: %d, zoomStartY: %d\n", zoomStartX, zoomStartY);
296            zoom -= zoomAmount;
297            startCacheX.pop();
298            startCacheY.pop();
299            startCacheX.add(Math.min(Math.max(startCacheX.pop() + (zoomCenterX >> zoom + 1) - (width >> zoom + 2),
300                    0), width - (width >> zoom)));
301            startCacheY.add(Math.min(Math.max(startCacheY.pop() + (zoomCenterY >> zoom + 1) - (height >> zoom + 2),
302                    0), height - (height >> zoom)));
303//            zoomStartX = Math.min(Math.max((zoomStartX >> 1) + (zoomCenterX >> zoom + 1) - (width >> zoom + 2),
304//                    0), width - (width >> zoom));
305//            zoomStartY = Math.min(Math.max((zoomStartY >> 1) + (zoomCenterY >> zoom + 1) - (height >> zoom + 2),
306//                    0), height - (height >> zoom));
307            regenerate(startX = (zoomStartX >> zoom) - (width >> zoom + 1), startY = (zoomStartY >> zoom) - (height >> zoom + 1),
308                    //startCacheX.peek(), startCacheY.peek(),
309                    usedWidth = width >> zoom,  usedHeight = height >> zoom,
310                    landModifier, heatModifier, cacheA, cacheB);
311            rng.setState(cacheA, cacheB);
312        }
313
314    }
315    /**
316     * Doubles the resolution of the map and halves the area it covers; the 2D arrays this uses keep their sizes. This
317     * version of zoomIn always zooms in to the center of the currently used area.
318     * <br>
319     * Although there is no technical restriction on maximum zoom, zooming in more than 5 times (64x scale or greater)
320     * will make the map appear somewhat less realistic due to rounded shapes appearing more bubble-like and less like a
321     * normal landscape.
322     */
323    public void zoomIn()
324    {
325        zoomIn(1, width >> 1, height >> 1);
326    }
327    /**
328     * Doubles the resolution of the map and halves the area it covers repeatedly, doubling {@code zoomAmount} times;
329     * the 2D arrays this uses keep their sizes. This version of zoomIn allows you to specify where the zoom should be
330     * centered, using the current coordinates (if the map size is 256x256, then coordinates should be between 0 and
331     * 255, and will refer to the currently used area and not necessarily the full world size).
332     * <br>
333     * Although there is no technical restriction on maximum zoom, zooming in more than 5 times (64x scale or greater)
334     * will make the map appear somewhat less realistic due to rounded shapes appearing more bubble-like and less like a
335     * normal landscape.
336     * @param zoomCenterX the center X position to zoom in to; if too close to an edge, this will stop moving before it would extend past an edge
337     * @param zoomCenterY the center Y position to zoom in to; if too close to an edge, this will stop moving before it would extend past an edge
338     */
339    public void zoomIn(int zoomAmount, int zoomCenterX, int zoomCenterY)
340    {
341        if(zoomAmount == 0) return;
342        if(zoomAmount < 0)
343        {
344            zoomOut(-zoomAmount, zoomCenterX, zoomCenterY);
345            return;
346        }
347        if(seedA != cacheA || seedB != cacheB)
348        {
349            generate(rng.nextLong());
350        }
351        zoomStartX = Math.min(Math.max(
352                (zoomStartX + zoomCenterX - (width >> 1) << zoomAmount),
353                width >> 1), (width << zoom + zoomAmount) - (width >> 1));
354//        int oldZoomY = zoomStartY;
355        zoomStartY = Math.min(Math.max(
356                (zoomStartY + zoomCenterY - (height >> 1) << zoomAmount),
357                height >> 1), (height << zoom + zoomAmount) - (height >> 1));
358//        System.out.printf("zoomIn, zoomStartX: %d, zoomStartY: %d, oldZoomY: %d, unedited: %d, upperCap: %d\n", zoomStartX, zoomStartY,
359//                oldZoomY, (oldZoomY + zoomCenterY - (height >> 1) << zoomAmount), (height << zoom + zoomAmount) - (height >> 1));
360        zoom += zoomAmount;
361        if(startCacheX.isEmpty())
362        {
363            startCacheX.add(0);
364            startCacheY.add(0);
365        }
366        else {
367            startCacheX.add(Math.min(Math.max(startCacheX.peek() + (zoomCenterX >> zoom - 1) - (width >> zoom + 1),
368                    0), width - (width >> zoom)));
369            startCacheY.add(Math.min(Math.max(startCacheY.peek() + (zoomCenterY >> zoom - 1) - (height >> zoom + 1),
370                    0), height - (height >> zoom)));
371        }
372        regenerate(startX = (zoomStartX >> zoom) - (width >> 1 + zoom), startY = (zoomStartY >> zoom) - (height >> 1 + zoom),
373                //startCacheX.peek(), startCacheY.peek(),
374                usedWidth = width >> zoom, usedHeight = height >> zoom,
375                landModifier, heatModifier, cacheA, cacheB);
376        rng.setState(cacheA, cacheB);
377    }
378
379    protected abstract void regenerate(int startX, int startY, int usedWidth, int usedHeight,
380                                       double landMod, double heatMod, int stateA, int stateB);
381    /**
382     * Given a latitude and longitude in radians (the conventional way of describing points on a globe), this gets the
383     * (x,y) Coord on the map projection this generator uses that corresponds to the given lat-lon coordinates. If this
384     * generator does not represent a globe (if it is toroidal, for instance) or if there is no "good way" to calculate
385     * the projection for a given lat-lon coordinate, this returns null. The default implementation always returns null.
386     * If this is a supported operation and the parameters are valid, this returns a Coord with x between 0 and
387     * {@link #width}, and y between 0 and {@link #height}, both exclusive. Automatically wraps the Coord's values using
388     * {@link #wrapX(int, int)} and {@link #wrapY(int, int)}.
389     * @param latitude the latitude, from {@code Math.PI * -0.5} to {@code Math.PI * 0.5}
390     * @param longitude the longitude, from {@code 0.0} to {@code Math.PI * 2.0}
391     * @return the point at the given latitude and longitude, as a Coord with x between 0 and {@link #width} and y between 0 and {@link #height}, or null if unsupported
392     */
393    public Coord project(double latitude, double longitude)
394    {
395        return null;
396    }
397
398    public int codeHeight(final double high)
399    {
400        if(high < deepWaterUpper)
401            return 0;
402        if(high < mediumWaterUpper)
403            return 1;
404        if(high < shallowWaterUpper)
405            return 2;
406        if(high < coastalWaterUpper)
407            return 3;
408        if(high < sandUpper)
409            return 4;
410        if(high < grassUpper)
411            return 5;
412        if(high < forestUpper)
413            return 6;
414        if(high < rockUpper)
415            return 7;
416        return 8;
417    }
418    protected final int decodeX(final int coded)
419    {
420        return coded % width;
421    }
422    protected final int decodeY(final int coded)
423    {
424        return coded / width;
425    }
426    public int wrapX(final int x, final int y)  {
427        return (x + width) % width;
428    }
429    public int wrapY(final int x, final int y)  {
430        return (y + height) % height;
431    }

690
691    public interface BiomeMapper
692    {
693        /**
694         * Gets the most relevant biome code for a given x,y point on the map. Some mappers can store more than one
695         * biome at a location, but only the one with the highest influence will be returned by this method. Biome codes
696         * are always ints, and are typically between 0 and 60, both inclusive; they are meant to be used as indices
697         * into a table of names or other objects that identify a biome, accessible via {@link #getBiomeNameTable()}.
698         * Although different classes may define biome codes differently, they should all be able to be used as indices
699         * into the String array returned by getBiomeNameTable().
700         * @param x the x-coordinate on the map
701         * @param y the y-coordinate on the map
702         * @return an int that can be used as an index into the array returned by {@link #getBiomeNameTable()}
703         */
704        int getBiomeCode(int x, int y);
705
706        /**
707         * Gets a heat code for a given x,y point on a map, usually as an int between 0 and 5 inclusive. Some
708         * implementations may use more or less detail for heat codes, but 0 is always the coldest code used, and the
709         * highest value this can return for a given implementation refers to the hottest code used.
710         * @param x the x-coordinate on the map
711         * @param y the y-coordinate on the map
712         * @return an int that can be used to categorize how hot an area is, with 0 as coldest
713         */
714        int getHeatCode(int x, int y);
715        /**
716         * Gets a moisture code for a given x,y point on a map, usually as an int between 0 and 5 inclusive. Some
717         * implementations may use more or less detail for moisture codes, but 0 is always the driest code used, and the
718         * highest value this can return for a given implementation refers to the wettest code used. Some
719         * implementations may allow seasonal change in moisture, e.g. monsoon seasons, to be modeled differently from
720         * average precipitation in an area, but the default assumption is that this describes the average amount of
721         * moisture (rain, humidity, and possibly snow/hail or other precipitation) that an area receives annually.
722         * @param x the x-coordinate on the map
723         * @param y the y-coordinate on the map
724         * @return an int that can be used to categorize how much moisture an area tends to receive, with 0 as driest
725         */
726        int getMoistureCode(int x, int y);
727
728        /**
729         * Gets a String array where biome codes can be used as indices to look up a name for the biome they refer to. A
730         * sample table is in {@link SimpleBiomeMapper#biomeTable}; the 61-element array format documented for that
731         * field is encouraged for implementing classes if they use 6 levels of heat and 6 levels of moisture, and track
732         * rivers, coastlines, lakes, and oceans as potentially different types of terrain. Biome codes can be obtained
733         * with {@link #getBiomeCode(int, int)}, or for some implementing classes other methods may provide more
734         * detailed information.
735         * @return a String array that often contains 61 elements, to be used with biome codes as indices.
736         */
737        String[] getBiomeNameTable();
738        /**
739         * Analyzes the last world produced by the given WorldMapGenerator and uses all of its generated information to
740         * assign biome codes for each cell (along with heat and moisture codes). After calling this, biome codes can be
741         * retrieved with {@link #getBiomeCode(int, int)} and used as indices into {@link #getBiomeNameTable()} or a
742         * custom biome table.
743         * @param world a WorldMapGenerator that should have generated at least one map; it may be at any zoom
744         */
745        void makeBiomes(WorldMapGenerator world);
746    }
747    /**
748     * A way to get biome information for the cells on a map when you only need a single value to describe a biome, such
749     * as "Grassland" or "TropicalRainforest".
750     * <br>
751     * To use: 1, Construct a SimpleBiomeMapper (constructor takes no arguments). 2, call
752     * {@link #makeBiomes(WorldMapGenerator)} with a WorldMapGenerator that has already produced at least one world map.
753     * 3, get biome codes from the {@link #biomeCodeData} field, where a code is an int that can be used as an index
754     * into the {@link #biomeTable} static field to get a String name for a biome type, or used with an alternate biome
755     * table of your design. Biome tables in this case are 61-element arrays organized into groups of 6 elements, with
756     * the last element reserved for empty space where the map doesn't cover (as with some map projections). Each
757     * group goes from the coldest temperature first to the warmest temperature last in the group. The first group of 6
758     * contains the dryest biomes, the next 6 are medium-dry, the next are slightly-dry, the next slightly-wet, then
759     * medium-wet, then wettest. After this first block of dry-to-wet groups, there is a group of 6 for coastlines, a
760     * group of 6 for rivers, a group of 6 for lakes, a group of 6 for oceans, and then one element for space outside
761     * the map. The last element, with code 60, is by convention the String "Empty", but normally the code should be
762     * enough to tell that a space is off-map. This also assigns moisture codes and heat codes from 0 to 5 for each
763     * cell, which may be useful to simplify logic that deals with those factors.
764     */
765    public static class SimpleBiomeMapper implements BiomeMapper
766    {
767        /**
768         * The heat codes for the analyzed map, from 0 to 5 inclusive, with 0 coldest and 5 hottest.
769         */
770        public int[][] heatCodeData,
771        /**
772         * The moisture codes for the analyzed map, from 0 to 5 inclusive, with 0 driest and 5 wettest.
773         */
774        moistureCodeData,
775        /**
776         * The biome codes for the analyzed map, from 0 to 60 inclusive. You can use {@link #biomeTable} to look up
777         * String names for biomes, or construct your own table as you see fit (see docs in {@link SimpleBiomeMapper}).
778         */
779        biomeCodeData;
780
781        @Override
782        public int getBiomeCode(int x, int y) {
783            return biomeCodeData[x][y];
784        }
785
786        @Override
787        public int getHeatCode(int x, int y) {
788            return heatCodeData[x][y];
789        }
790
791        @Override
792        public int getMoistureCode(int x, int y) {
793            return moistureCodeData[x][y];
794        }
795
796        /**
797         * Gets a String array where biome codes can be used as indices to look up a name for the biome they refer to.
798         * This table uses 6 levels of heat and 6 levels of moisture, and tracks rivers, coastlines, lakes, and oceans
799         * as potentially different types of terrain. Biome codes can be obtained with {@link #getBiomeCode(int, int)}.
800         * This method returns a direct reference to {@link #biomeTable}, so modifying the returned array is discouraged
801         * (you should implement {@link BiomeMapper} using this class as a basis if you want to change its size).
802         * @return a direct reference to {@link #biomeTable}, a String array containing names of biomes
803         */
804        @Override
805        public String[] getBiomeNameTable() {
806            return biomeTable;
807        }
808
809        public static final double
810                coldestValueLower = 0.0,   coldestValueUpper = 0.15, // 0
811                colderValueLower = 0.15,   colderValueUpper = 0.31,  // 1
812                coldValueLower = 0.31,     coldValueUpper = 0.5,     // 2
813                warmValueLower = 0.5,      warmValueUpper = 0.69,    // 3
814                warmerValueLower = 0.69,   warmerValueUpper = 0.85,  // 4
815                warmestValueLower = 0.85,  warmestValueUpper = 1.0,  // 5
816
817        driestValueLower = 0.0,    driestValueUpper  = 0.27, // 0
818                drierValueLower = 0.27,    drierValueUpper   = 0.4,  // 1
819                dryValueLower = 0.4,       dryValueUpper     = 0.6,  // 2
820                wetValueLower = 0.6,       wetValueUpper     = 0.8,  // 3
821                wetterValueLower = 0.8,    wetterValueUpper  = 0.9,  // 4
822                wettestValueLower = 0.9,   wettestValueUpper = 1.0;  // 5
823
824        /**
825         * The default biome table to use with biome codes from {@link #biomeCodeData}. Biomes are assigned based on
826         * heat and moisture for the first 36 of 61 elements (coldest to warmest for each group of 6, with the first
827         * group as the dryest and the last group the wettest), then the next 6 are for coastlines (coldest to warmest),
828         * then rivers (coldest to warmest), then lakes (coldest to warmest), then oceans (coldest to warmest), and
829         * lastly a single "biome" for empty space outside the map (meant for projections that don't fill a rectangle).
830         */
831        public static final String[] biomeTable = {
832                //COLDEST //COLDER        //COLD            //HOT                  //HOTTER              //HOTTEST
833                "Ice",    "Ice",          "Grassland",      "Desert",              "Desert",             "Desert",             //DRYEST
834                "Ice",    "Tundra",       "Grassland",      "Grassland",           "Desert",             "Desert",             //DRYER
835                "Ice",    "Tundra",       "Woodland",       "Woodland",            "Savanna",            "Desert",             //DRY
836                "Ice",    "Tundra",       "SeasonalForest", "SeasonalForest",      "Savanna",            "Savanna",            //WET
837                "Ice",    "Tundra",       "BorealForest",   "TemperateRainforest", "TropicalRainforest", "Savanna",            //WETTER
838                "Ice",    "BorealForest", "BorealForest",   "TemperateRainforest", "TropicalRainforest", "TropicalRainforest", //WETTEST
839                "Rocky",  "Rocky",        "Beach",          "Beach",               "Beach",              "Beach",              //COASTS
840                "Ice",    "River",        "River",          "River",               "River",              "River",              //RIVERS
841                "Ice",    "River",        "River",          "River",               "River",              "River",              //LAKES
842                "Ocean",  "Ocean",        "Ocean",          "Ocean",               "Ocean",              "Ocean",              //OCEAN
843                "Empty",                                                                                                       //SPACE
844        };
845
846        /**
847         * Simple constructor; pretty much does nothing. Make sure to call {@link #makeBiomes(WorldMapGenerator)} before
848         * using fields like {@link #biomeCodeData}.
849         */
850        public SimpleBiomeMapper()
851        {
852            heatCodeData = null;
853            moistureCodeData = null;
854            biomeCodeData = null;
855        }
856
857        /**
858         * Analyzes the last world produced by the given WorldMapGenerator and uses all of its generated information to
859         * assign biome codes for each cell (along with heat and moisture codes). After calling this, biome codes can be
860         * taken from {@link #biomeCodeData} and used as indices into {@link #biomeTable} or a custom biome table.
861         * @param world a WorldMapGenerator that should have generated at least one map; it may be at any zoom
862         */
863        @Override
864        public void makeBiomes(WorldMapGenerator world) {
865            if(world == null || world.width <= 0 || world.height <= 0)
866                return;
867            if(heatCodeData == null || (heatCodeData.length != world.width || heatCodeData[0].length != world.height))
868                heatCodeData = new int[world.width][world.height];
869            if(moistureCodeData == null || (moistureCodeData.length != world.width || moistureCodeData[0].length != world.height))
870                moistureCodeData = new int[world.width][world.height];
871            if(biomeCodeData == null || (biomeCodeData.length != world.width || biomeCodeData[0].length != world.height))
872                biomeCodeData = new int[world.width][world.height];
873            final double i_hot = (world.maxHeat == world.minHeat) ? 1.0 : 1.0 / (world.maxHeat - world.minHeat);
874            for (int x = 0; x < world.width; x++) {
875                for (int y = 0; y < world.height; y++) {
876                    final double hot = (world.heatData[x][y] - world.minHeat) * i_hot, moist = world.moistureData[x][y];
877                    final int heightCode = world.heightCodeData[x][y];
878                    if(heightCode == 1000) {
879                        biomeCodeData[x][y] = 60;
880                        continue;
881                    }
882                    int hc, mc;
883                    boolean isLake = false,// world.generateRivers && heightCode >= 4 && fresh > 0.65 && fresh + moist * 2.35 > 2.75,//world.partialLakeData.contains(x, y) && heightCode >= 4,
884                            isRiver = false;// world.generateRivers && !isLake && heightCode >= 4 && fresh > 0.55 && fresh + moist * 2.2 > 2.15;//world.partialRiverData.contains(x, y) && heightCode >= 4;
885                    if(heightCode < 4) {
886                        mc = 9;
887                    }
888                    else if (moist > wetterValueUpper) {
889                        mc = 5;
890                    } else if (moist > wetValueUpper) {
891                        mc = 4;
892                    } else if (moist > dryValueUpper) {
893                        mc = 3;
894                    } else if (moist > drierValueUpper) {
895                        mc = 2;
896                    } else if (moist > driestValueUpper) {
897                        mc = 1;
898                    } else {
899                        mc = 0;
900                    }
901
902                    if (hot > warmerValueUpper) {
903                        hc = 5;
904                    } else if (hot > warmValueUpper) {
905                        hc = 4;
906                    } else if (hot > coldValueUpper) {
907                        hc = 3;
908                    } else if (hot > colderValueUpper) {
909                        hc = 2;
910                    } else if (hot > coldestValueUpper) {
911                        hc = 1;
912                    } else {
913                        hc = 0;
914                    }
915
916                    heatCodeData[x][y] = hc;
917                    moistureCodeData[x][y] = mc;
918                    biomeCodeData[x][y] = heightCode < 4 ? hc + 54 // 54 == 9 * 6, 9 is used for Ocean groups
919                            : isLake ? hc + 48 : (isRiver ? hc + 42 : ((heightCode == 4) ? hc + 36 : hc + mc * 6));
920                }
921            }
922        }
923    }
924    /**
925     * A way to get biome information for the cells on a map when you want an area's biome to be a combination of two
926     * main biome types, such as "Grassland" or "TropicalRainforest", with the biomes varying in weight between areas.
927     * <br>
928     * To use: 1, Construct a DetailedBiomeMapper (constructor takes no arguments). 2, call
929     * {@link #makeBiomes(WorldMapGenerator)} with a WorldMapGenerator that has already produced at least one world map.
930     * 3, get biome codes from the {@link #biomeCodeData} field, where a code is an int that can be used with the
931     * extract methods in this class to get various information from it (these are {@link #extractBiomeA(int)},
932     * {@link #extractBiomeB(int)}, {@link #extractPartA(int)}, {@link #extractPartB(int)}, and
933     * {@link #extractMixAmount(int)}). You can get predefined names for biomes using the extractBiome methods (these
934     * names can be changed in {@link #biomeTable}), or raw indices into some (usually 61-element) collection or array
935     * with the extractPart methods. The extractMixAmount() method gets a float that is the amount by which biome B
936     * affects biome A; if this is higher than 0.5, then biome B is the "dominant" biome in the area.
937     */
938    public static class DetailedBiomeMapper implements BiomeMapper
939    {
940        /**
941         * The heat codes for the analyzed map, from 0 to 5 inclusive, with 0 coldest and 5 hottest.
942         */
943        public int[][] heatCodeData,
944        /**
945         * The moisture codes for the analyzed map, from 0 to 5 inclusive, with 0 driest and 5 wettest.
946         */
947        moistureCodeData,
948        /**
949         * The biome codes for the analyzed map, using one int to store the codes for two biomes and the degree by which
950         * the second biome affects the first. These codes can be used with methods in this class like
951         * {@link #extractBiomeA(int)}, {@link #extractBiomeB(int)}, and {@link #extractMixAmount(int)} to find the two
952         * dominant biomes in an area, called biome A and biome B, and the mix amount, for finding how much biome B
953         * affects biome A.
954         */
955        biomeCodeData;
956
957        @Override
958        public int getBiomeCode(int x, int y) {
959            int code = biomeCodeData[x][y];
960            if(code < 0x2000000) return code & 1023;
961            return (code >>> 10) & 1023;
962        }
963
964        @Override
965        public int getHeatCode(int x, int y) {
966            return heatCodeData[x][y];
967        }
968
969        @Override
970        public int getMoistureCode(int x, int y) {
971            return moistureCodeData[x][y];
972        }
973
974        /**
975         * Gets a String array where biome codes can be used as indices to look up a name for the biome they refer to.
976         * This table uses 6 levels of heat and 6 levels of moisture, and tracks rivers, coastlines, lakes, and oceans
977         * as potentially different types of terrain. Biome codes can be obtained with {@link #getBiomeCode(int, int)}.
978         * This method returns a direct reference to {@link #biomeTable}, so modifying the returned array is discouraged
979         * (you should implement {@link BiomeMapper} using this class as a basis if you want to change its size).
980         * @return a direct reference to {@link #biomeTable}, a String array containing names of biomes
981         */
982        @Override
983        public String[] getBiomeNameTable() {
984            return biomeTable;
985        }
986
987        public static final double
988                coldestValueLower = 0.0,   coldestValueUpper = 0.15, // 0
989                colderValueLower = 0.15,   colderValueUpper = 0.31,  // 1
990                coldValueLower = 0.31,     coldValueUpper = 0.5,     // 2
991                warmValueLower = 0.5,      warmValueUpper = 0.69,     // 3
992                warmerValueLower = 0.69,    warmerValueUpper = 0.85,   // 4
993                warmestValueLower = 0.85,   warmestValueUpper = 1.0,  // 5
994
995        driestValueLower = 0.0,    driestValueUpper  = 0.27, // 0
996                drierValueLower = 0.27,    drierValueUpper   = 0.4,  // 1
997                dryValueLower = 0.4,       dryValueUpper     = 0.6,  // 2
998                wetValueLower = 0.6,       wetValueUpper     = 0.8,  // 3
999                wetterValueLower = 0.8,    wetterValueUpper  = 0.9,  // 4
1000                wettestValueLower = 0.9,   wettestValueUpper = 1.0;  // 5
1001
1002        /**
1003         * The default biome table to use with parts of biome codes from {@link #biomeCodeData}. Biomes are assigned by
1004         * heat and moisture for the first 36 of 61 elements (coldest to warmest for each group of 6, with the first
1005         * group as the dryest and the last group the wettest), then the next 6 are for coastlines (coldest to warmest),
1006         * then rivers (coldest to warmest), then lakes (coldest to warmest). The last is reserved for empty space.
1007         * <br>
1008         * Unlike with {@link SimpleBiomeMapper}, you cannot use a biome code directly from biomeCodeData as an index
1009         * into this in almost any case; you should pass the biome code to one of the extract methods.
1010         * {@link #extractBiomeA(int)} or {@link #extractBiomeB(int)} will work if you want a biome name, or
1011         * {@link #extractPartA(int)} or {@link #extractPartB(int)} should be used if you want a non-coded int that
1012         * represents one of the biomes' indices into something like this. You can also get the amount by which biome B
1013         * is affecting biome A with {@link #extractMixAmount(int)}.
1014         */
1015        public static final String[] biomeTable = {
1016                //COLDEST //COLDER        //COLD            //HOT                  //HOTTER              //HOTTEST
1017                "Ice",    "Ice",          "Grassland",      "Desert",              "Desert",             "Desert",             //DRYEST
1018                "Ice",    "Tundra",       "Grassland",      "Grassland",           "Desert",             "Desert",             //DRYER
1019                "Ice",    "Tundra",       "Woodland",       "Woodland",            "Savanna",            "Desert",             //DRY
1020                "Ice",    "Tundra",       "SeasonalForest", "SeasonalForest",      "Savanna",            "Savanna",            //WET
1021                "Ice",    "Tundra",       "BorealForest",   "TemperateRainforest", "TropicalRainforest", "Savanna",            //WETTER
1022                "Ice",    "BorealForest", "BorealForest",   "TemperateRainforest", "TropicalRainforest", "TropicalRainforest", //WETTEST
1023                "Rocky",  "Rocky",        "Beach",          "Beach",               "Beach",              "Beach",              //COASTS
1024                "Ice",    "River",        "River",          "River",               "River",              "River",              //RIVERS
1025                "Ice",    "River",        "River",          "River",               "River",              "River",              //LAKES
1026                "Ocean",  "Ocean",        "Ocean",          "Ocean",               "Ocean",              "Ocean",              //OCEAN
1027                "Empty",                                                                                                       //SPACE
1028        };
1029
1030        /**
1031         * Gets the int stored in part A of the given biome code, which can be used as an index into other collections.
1032         * This int should almost always range from 0 to 60 (both inclusive), so collections this is used as an index
1033         * for should have a length of at least 61.
1034         * @param biomeCode a biome code that was probably received from {@link #biomeCodeData}
1035         * @return an int stored in the biome code's part A; almost always between 0 and 60, inclusive.
1036         */
1037        public int extractPartA(int biomeCode)
1038        {
1039            return biomeCode & 1023;
1040        }
1041        /**
1042         * Gets a String from {@link #biomeTable} that names the appropriate biome in part A of the given biome code.
1043         * @param biomeCode a biome code that was probably received from {@link #biomeCodeData}
1044         * @return a String that names the biome in part A of biomeCode, or "Empty" if none can be found
1045         */
1046        public String extractBiomeA(int biomeCode)
1047        {
1048            biomeCode &= 1023;
1049            if(biomeCode < 60)
1050                return biomeTable[biomeCode];
1051            return "Empty";
1052        }
1053        /**
1054         * Gets the int stored in part B of the given biome code, which can be used as an index into other collections.
1055         * This int should almost always range from 0 to 60 (both inclusive), so collections this is used as an index
1056         * for should have a length of at least 61.
1057         * @param biomeCode a biome code that was probably received from {@link #biomeCodeData}
1058         * @return an int stored in the biome code's part B; almost always between 0 and 60, inclusive.
1059         */
1060        public int extractPartB(int biomeCode)
1061        {
1062            return (biomeCode >>> 10) & 1023;
1063        }
1064
1065        /**
1066         * Gets a String from {@link #biomeTable} that names the appropriate biome in part B of the given biome code.
1067         * @param biomeCode a biome code that was probably received from {@link #biomeCodeData}
1068         * @return a String that names the biome in part B of biomeCode, or "Ocean" if none can be found
1069         */
1070        public String extractBiomeB(int biomeCode)
1071        {
1072            biomeCode = (biomeCode >>> 10) & 1023;
1073            if(biomeCode < 60)
1074                return biomeTable[biomeCode];
1075            return "Empty";
1076        }
1077
1078        /**
1079         * This gets the portion of a biome code that represents the amount of mixing between two biomes.
1080         * Biome codes are normally obtained from the {@link #biomeCodeData} field, and aren't very usable on their own
1081         * without calling methods like this, {@link #extractBiomeA(int)}, and {@link #extractBiomeB(int)}. This returns
1082         * a float between 0.0f (inclusive) and 1.0f (exclusive), with 0.0f meaning biome B has no effect on an area and
1083         * biome A is the only one used, 0.5f meaning biome A and biome B have equal effect, and 0.75f meaning biome B
1084         * has most of the effect, three-fourths of the area, and biome A has less, one-fourth of the area.
1085         * @param biomeCode a biome code that was probably received from {@link #biomeCodeData}
1086         * @return a float between 0.0f (inclusive) and 1.0f (exclusive) representing mixing of biome B into biome A
1087         */
1088        public float extractMixAmount(int biomeCode)
1089        {
1090            return (biomeCode >>> 20) * 0x1p-10f;
1091        }
1092
1093        /**
1094         * Simple constructor; pretty much does nothing. Make sure to call {@link #makeBiomes(WorldMapGenerator)} before
1095         * using fields like {@link #biomeCodeData}.
1096         */
1097        public DetailedBiomeMapper()
1098        {
1099            heatCodeData = null;
1100            moistureCodeData = null;
1101            biomeCodeData = null;
1102        }
1103
1104        /**
1105         * Analyzes the last world produced by the given WorldMapGenerator and uses all of its generated information to
1106         * assign biome codes for each cell (along with heat and moisture codes). After calling this, biome codes can be
1107         * taken from {@link #biomeCodeData} and used with methods in this class like {@link #extractBiomeA(int)},
1108         * {@link #extractBiomeB(int)}, and {@link #extractMixAmount(int)} to find the two dominant biomes in an area,
1109         * called biome A and biome B, and the mix amount, for finding how much biome B affects biome A.
1110         * @param world a WorldMapGenerator that should have generated at least one map; it may be at any zoom
1111         */
1112        @Override
1113        public void makeBiomes(WorldMapGenerator world) {
1114            if(world == null || world.width <= 0 || world.height <= 0)
1115                return;
1116            if(heatCodeData == null || (heatCodeData.length != world.width || heatCodeData[0].length != world.height))
1117                heatCodeData = new int[world.width][world.height];
1118            if(moistureCodeData == null || (moistureCodeData.length != world.width || moistureCodeData[0].length != world.height))
1119                moistureCodeData = new int[world.width][world.height];
1120            if(biomeCodeData == null || (biomeCodeData.length != world.width || biomeCodeData[0].length != world.height))
1121                biomeCodeData = new int[world.width][world.height];
1122            final int[][] heightCodeData = world.heightCodeData;
1123            final double[][] heatData = world.heatData, moistureData = world.moistureData, heightData = world.heightData;
1124            int hc, mc, heightCode, bc;
1125            double hot, moist, high, i_hot = 1.0 / world.maxHeat, fresh;
1126            for (int x = 0; x < world.width; x++) {
1127                for (int y = 0; y < world.height; y++) {
1128
1129                    heightCode = heightCodeData[x][y];
1130                    if(heightCode == 1000) {
1131                        biomeCodeData[x][y] = 61;
1132                        continue;
1133                    }
1134                    hot = heatData[x][y];
1135                    moist = moistureData[x][y];
1136                    high = heightData[x][y];
1137//                    fresh = world.freshwaterData[x][y];
1138                    boolean isLake = false,//world.generateRivers && heightCode >= 4 && fresh > 0.65 && fresh + moist * 2.35 > 2.75,//world.partialLakeData.contains(x, y) && heightCode >= 4,
1139                            isRiver = false;//world.generateRivers && !isLake && heightCode >= 4 && fresh > 0.55 && fresh + moist * 2.2 > 2.15;//world.partialRiverData.contains(x, y) && heightCode >= 4;
1140                    if (moist >= (wettestValueUpper - (wetterValueUpper - wetterValueLower) * 0.2)) {
1141                        mc = 5;
1142                    } else if (moist >= (wetterValueUpper - (wetValueUpper - wetValueLower) * 0.2)) {
1143                        mc = 4;
1144                    } else if (moist >= (wetValueUpper - (dryValueUpper - dryValueLower) * 0.2)) {
1145                        mc = 3;
1146                    } else if (moist >= (dryValueUpper - (drierValueUpper - drierValueLower) * 0.2)) {
1147                        mc = 2;
1148                    } else if (moist >= (drierValueUpper - (driestValueUpper) * 0.2)) {
1149                        mc = 1;
1150                    } else {
1151                        mc = 0;
1152                    }
1153
1154                    if (hot >= (warmestValueUpper - (warmerValueUpper - warmerValueLower) * 0.2) * i_hot) {
1155                        hc = 5;
1156                    } else if (hot >= (warmerValueUpper - (warmValueUpper - warmValueLower) * 0.2) * i_hot) {
1157                        hc = 4;
1158                    } else if (hot >= (warmValueUpper - (coldValueUpper - coldValueLower) * 0.2) * i_hot) {
1159                        hc = 3;
1160                    } else if (hot >= (coldValueUpper - (colderValueUpper - colderValueLower) * 0.2) * i_hot) {
1161                        hc = 2;
1162                    } else if (hot >= (colderValueUpper - (coldestValueUpper) * 0.2) * i_hot) {
1163                        hc = 1;
1164                    } else {
1165                        hc = 0;
1166                    }
1167
1168                    heatCodeData[x][y] = hc;
1169                    moistureCodeData[x][y] = mc;
1170                    bc = heightCode < 4 ? hc + 54 // 54 == 9 * 6, 9 is used for Ocean groups
1171                            : isLake ? hc + 48 : (isRiver ? hc + 42 : ((heightCode == 4) ? hc + 36 : hc + mc * 6));
1172
1173                    if(heightCode < 4) {
1174                        mc = 9;
1175                    }
1176                    else if (moist >= (wetterValueUpper + (wettestValueUpper - wettestValueLower) * 0.2)) {
1177                        mc = 5;
1178                    } else if (moist >= (wetValueUpper + (wetterValueUpper - wetterValueLower) * 0.2)) {
1179                        mc = 4;
1180                    } else if (moist >= (dryValueUpper + (wetValueUpper - wetValueLower) * 0.2)) {
1181                        mc = 3;
1182                    } else if (moist >= (drierValueUpper + (dryValueUpper - dryValueLower) * 0.2)) {
1183                        mc = 2;
1184                    } else if (moist >= (driestValueUpper + (drierValueUpper - drierValueLower) * 0.2)) {
1185                        mc = 1;
1186                    } else {
1187                        mc = 0;
1188                    }
1189
1190                    if (hot >= (warmerValueUpper + (warmestValueUpper - warmestValueLower) * 0.2) * i_hot) {
1191                        hc = 5;
1192                    } else if (hot >= (warmValueUpper + (warmerValueUpper - warmerValueLower) * 0.2) * i_hot) {
1193                        hc = 4;
1194                    } else if (hot >= (coldValueUpper + (warmValueUpper - warmValueLower) * 0.2) * i_hot) {
1195                        hc = 3;
1196                    } else if (hot >= (colderValueUpper + (coldValueUpper - coldValueLower) * 0.2) * i_hot) {
1197                        hc = 2;
1198                    } else if (hot >= (coldestValueUpper + (colderValueUpper - colderValueLower) * 0.2) * i_hot) {
1199                        hc = 1;
1200                    } else {
1201                        hc = 0;
1202                    }
1203
1204                    bc |= (hc + mc * 6) << 10;
1205                    if(heightCode < 4)
1206                        biomeCodeData[x][y] = bc | (int)((heightData[x][y] + 1.0) * 1000.0) << 20;
1207                    else if (isRiver || isLake)
1208                        biomeCodeData[x][y] = bc | (int)(moist * 358.4 + 665.0) << 20;
1209                    else
1210                        biomeCodeData[x][y] = bc | (int) ((heightCode == 4)
1211                                ? (sandUpper - high) * 10240.0 // multiplier affected by changes to sandLower
1212                                : NumberTools.sway((high + moist) * (4.1 + high - hot)) * 512 + 512) << 20;
1213                }
1214            }
1215        }
1216    }
1217
1218    /**
1219     * A concrete implementation of {@link WorldMapGenerator} that tiles both east-to-west and north-to-south. It tends
1220     * to not appear distorted like {@link SphereMap} does in some areas, even though this is inaccurate for a
1221     * rectangular projection of a spherical world (that inaccuracy is likely what players expect in a map, though).
1222     * <a href="http://squidpony.github.io/SquidLib/DetailedWorldMapRiverDemo.png" >Example map</a>.
1223     */
1224    public static class TilingMap extends WorldMapGenerator {
1225        //protected static final double terrainFreq = 1.5, terrainRidgedFreq = 1.3, heatFreq = 2.8, moistureFreq = 2.9, otherFreq = 4.5;
1226//        protected static final double terrainFreq = 1.175, terrainRidgedFreq = 1.3, heatFreq = 2.3, moistureFreq = 2.4, otherFreq = 3.5;
1227        protected static final double terrainFreq = 0.95, terrainRidgedFreq = 3.1, heatFreq = 2.1, moistureFreq = 2.125, otherFreq = 3.375;
1228        private double minHeat0 = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY, maxHeat0 = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY,
1229                minHeat1 = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY, maxHeat1 = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY,
1230                minWet0 = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY, maxWet0 = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY;
1231
1232        public final Noise4D terrain, terrainRidged, heat, moisture, otherRidged;
1233
1234        /**
1235         * Constructs a concrete WorldMapGenerator for a map that can be used as a tiling, wrapping east-to-west as well
1236         * as north-to-south. Always makes a 256x256 map.
1237         * Uses FastNoise as its noise generator, with 1.0 as the octave multiplier affecting detail.
1238         * If you were using {@link TilingMap#TilingMap(long, int, int, Noise4D, double)}, then this would be the
1239         * same as passing the parameters {@code 0x1337BABE1337D00DL, 256, 256, WorldMapGenerator.DEFAULT_NOISE, 1.0}.
1240         */
1241        public TilingMap() {
1242            this(0x1337BABE1337D00DL, 256, 256, WorldMapGenerator.DEFAULT_NOISE, 1.0);
1243        }
1244
1245        /**
1246         * Constructs a concrete WorldMapGenerator for a map that can be used as a tiling, wrapping east-to-west as well
1247         * as north-to-south.
1248         * Takes only the width/height of the map. The initial seed is set to the same large long
1249         * every time, and it's likely that you would set the seed when you call {@link #generate(long)}. The width and
1250         * height of the map cannot be changed after the fact, but you can zoom in.
1251         * Uses FastNoise as its noise generator, with 1.0 as the octave multiplier affecting detail.
1252         *
1253         * @param mapWidth  the width of the map(s) to generate; cannot be changed later
1254         * @param mapHeight the height of the map(s) to generate; cannot be changed later
1255         */
1256        public TilingMap(int mapWidth, int mapHeight) {
1257            this(0x1337BABE1337D00DL, mapWidth, mapHeight, DEFAULT_NOISE, 1.0);
1258        }
1259
1260        /**
1261         * Constructs a concrete WorldMapGenerator for a map that can be used as a tiling, wrapping east-to-west as well
1262         * as north-to-south.
1263         * Takes an initial seed and the width/height of the map. The {@code initialSeed}
1264         * parameter may or may not be used, since you can specify the seed to use when you call {@link #generate(long)}.
1265         * The width and height of the map cannot be changed after the fact, but you can zoom in.
1266         * Uses FastNoise as its noise generator, with 1.0 as the octave multiplier affecting detail.
1267         *
1268         * @param initialSeed the seed for the GWTRNG this uses; this may also be set per-call to generate
1269         * @param mapWidth    the width of the map(s) to generate; cannot be changed later
1270         * @param mapHeight   the height of the map(s) to generate; cannot be changed later
1271         */
1272        public TilingMap(long initialSeed, int mapWidth, int mapHeight) {
1273            this(initialSeed, mapWidth, mapHeight, DEFAULT_NOISE, 1.0);
1274        }
1275
1276        /**
1277         * Constructs a concrete WorldMapGenerator for a map that can be used as a tiling, wrapping east-to-west as well
1278         * as north-to-south. Takes an initial seed, the width/height of the map, and a noise generator (a
1279         * {@link Noise4D} implementation, which is usually {@link FastNoise#instance}. The {@code initialSeed}
1280         * parameter may or may not be used, since you can specify the seed to use when you call
1281         * {@link #generate(long)}. The width and height of the map cannot be changed after the fact, but you can zoom
1282         * in. Any seed supplied to the Noise4D given to this (if it takes one) will be ignored, and
1283         * {@link Noise4D#getNoiseWithSeed(double, double, double, double, long)} will be used to specify the seed many
1284         * times. The detail level, which is the {@code octaveMultiplier} parameter that can be passed to another
1285         * constructor, is always 1.0 with this constructor.
1286         *
1287         * @param initialSeed      the seed for the GWTRNG this uses; this may also be set per-call to generate
1288         * @param mapWidth         the width of the map(s) to generate; cannot be changed later
1289         * @param mapHeight        the height of the map(s) to generate; cannot be changed later
1290         * @param noiseGenerator   an instance of a noise generator capable of 4D noise, recommended to be {@link FastNoise#instance}
1291         */
1292        public TilingMap(long initialSeed, int mapWidth, int mapHeight, final Noise4D noiseGenerator) {
1293            this(initialSeed, mapWidth, mapHeight, noiseGenerator, 1.0);
1294        }
1295
1296        /**
1297         * Constructs a concrete WorldMapGenerator for a map that can be used as a tiling, wrapping east-to-west as well
1298         * as north-to-south. Takes an initial seed, the width/height of the map, and parameters for noise
1299         * generation (a {@link Noise4D} implementation, which is usually {@link FastNoise#instance}, and a
1300         * multiplier on how many octaves of noise to use, with 1.0 being normal (high) detail and higher multipliers
1301         * producing even more detailed noise when zoomed-in). The {@code initialSeed} parameter may or may not be used,
1302         * since you can specify the seed to use when you call {@link #generate(long)}. The width and height of the map
1303         * cannot be changed after the fact, but you can zoom in. Any seed supplied to the Noise4D given to this (if it takes one) will be ignored, and
1304         * {@link Noise4D#getNoiseWithSeed(double, double, double, double, long)} will be used to specify the seed many
1305         * times. The {@code octaveMultiplier} parameter should probably be no lower than 0.5, but can be arbitrarily
1306         * high if you're willing to spend much more time on generating detail only noticeable at very high zoom;
1307         * normally 1.0 is fine and may even be too high for maps that don't require zooming.
1308         * @param initialSeed the seed for the GWTRNG this uses; this may also be set per-call to generate
1309         * @param mapWidth the width of the map(s) to generate; cannot be changed later
1310         * @param mapHeight the height of the map(s) to generate; cannot be changed later
1311         * @param noiseGenerator an instance of a noise generator capable of 4D noise, almost always {@link FastNoise}
1312         * @param octaveMultiplier used to adjust the level of detail, with 0.5 at the bare-minimum detail and 1.0 normal
1313         */
1314        public TilingMap(long initialSeed, int mapWidth, int mapHeight, final Noise4D noiseGenerator, double octaveMultiplier) {
1315            super(initialSeed, mapWidth, mapHeight);
1316            terrain = new Noise.InverseLayered4D(noiseGenerator, (int) (0.5 + octaveMultiplier * 8), terrainFreq);
1317            terrainRidged = new Noise.Ridged4D(noiseGenerator, (int) (0.5 + octaveMultiplier * 10), terrainRidgedFreq);
1318            heat = new Noise.InverseLayered4D(noiseGenerator, (int) (0.5 + octaveMultiplier * 3), heatFreq);
1319            moisture = new Noise.InverseLayered4D(noiseGenerator, (int) (0.5 + octaveMultiplier * 4), moistureFreq);
1320            otherRidged = new Noise.Ridged4D(noiseGenerator, (int) (0.5 + octaveMultiplier * 6), otherFreq);
1321        }
1322
1323        /**
1324         * Copies the TilingMap {@code other} to construct a new one that is exactly the same. References will only be
1325         * shared to Noise classes.
1326         * @param other a TilingMap to copy
1327         */
1328        public TilingMap(TilingMap other)
1329        {
1330            super(other);
1331            terrain = other.terrain;
1332            terrainRidged = other.terrainRidged;
1333            heat = other.heat;
1334            moisture = other.moisture;
1335            otherRidged = other.otherRidged;
1336            minHeat0 = other.minHeat0;
1337            maxHeat0 = other.maxHeat0;
1338            minHeat1 = other.minHeat1;
1339            maxHeat1 = other.maxHeat1;
1340            minWet0 = other.minWet0;
1341            maxWet0 = other.maxWet0;
1342        }
1343
1344        protected void regenerate(int startX, int startY, int usedWidth, int usedHeight,
1345                                  double landMod, double heatMod, int stateA, int stateB)
1346        {
1347            boolean fresh = false;
1348            if(cacheA != stateA || cacheB != stateB || landMod != landModifier || heatMod != heatModifier)
1349            {
1350                minHeight = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY;
1351                maxHeight = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY;
1352                minHeat0 = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY;
1353                maxHeat0 = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY;
1354                minHeat1 = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY;
1355                maxHeat1 = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY;
1356                minHeat = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY;
1357                maxHeat = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY;
1358                minWet0 = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY;
1359                maxWet0 = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY;
1360                minWet = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY;
1361                maxWet = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY;
1362                cacheA = stateA;
1363                cacheB = stateB;
1364                fresh = true;
1365            }
1366            rng.setState(stateA, stateB);
1367            long seedA = rng.nextLong(), seedB = rng.nextLong(), seedC = rng.nextLong();
1368            int t;
1369
1370            landModifier = (landMod <= 0) ? rng.nextDouble(0.1875) + 0.99 : landMod;
1371            heatModifier = (heatMod <= 0) ? rng.nextDouble(0.45) * (rng.nextDouble()-0.5) + 1.1 : heatMod;
1372
1373            double p, q,
1374                    ps, pc,
1375                    qs, qc,
1376                    h, temp,
1377                    i_w = 6.283185307179586 / width, i_h = 6.283185307179586 / height,
1378                    xPos = startX, yPos = startY, i_uw = usedWidth / (double)width, i_uh = usedHeight / (double)height;
1379            double[] trigTable = new double[width << 1];
1380            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++, xPos += i_uw) {
1381                p = xPos * i_w;
1382                trigTable[x<<1]   = NumberTools.sin(p);
1383                trigTable[x<<1|1] = NumberTools.cos(p);
1384            }
1385            for (int y = 0; y < height; y++, yPos += i_uh) {
1386                q = yPos * i_h;
1387                qs = NumberTools.sin(q);
1388                qc = NumberTools.cos(q);
1389                for (int x = 0, xt = 0; x < width; x++) {
1390                    ps = trigTable[xt++];//NumberTools.sin(p);
1391                    pc = trigTable[xt++];//NumberTools.cos(p);
1392                    heightData[x][y] = (h = terrain.getNoiseWithSeed(pc +
1393                                    terrainRidged.getNoiseWithSeed(pc, ps, qc, qs,seedB - seedA) * 0.25,
1394                            ps, qc, qs, seedA) + landModifier - 1.0);
1395                    heatData[x][y] = (p = heat.getNoiseWithSeed(pc, ps, qc
1396                                    + otherRidged.getNoiseWithSeed(pc, ps, qc, qs, seedB + seedC)
1397                            , qs, seedB));
1398                    moistureData[x][y] = (temp = moisture.getNoiseWithSeed(pc, ps, qc, qs
1399                                    + otherRidged.getNoiseWithSeed(pc, ps, qc, qs, seedC + seedA)
1400                            , seedC));
1401                    minHeightActual = Math.min(minHeightActual, h);
1402                    maxHeightActual = Math.max(maxHeightActual, h);
1403                    if(fresh) {
1404                        minHeight = Math.min(minHeight, h);
1405                        maxHeight = Math.max(maxHeight, h);
1406
1407                        minHeat0 = Math.min(minHeat0, p);
1408                        maxHeat0 = Math.max(maxHeat0, p);
1409
1410                        minWet0 = Math.min(minWet0, temp);
1411                        maxWet0 = Math.max(maxWet0, temp);
1412
1413                    }
1414                }
1415                minHeightActual = Math.min(minHeightActual, minHeight);
1416                maxHeightActual = Math.max(maxHeightActual, maxHeight);
1417
1418            }
1419            double heightDiff = 2.0 / (maxHeightActual - minHeightActual),
1420                    heatDiff = 0.8 / (maxHeat0 - minHeat0),
1421                    wetDiff = 1.0 / (maxWet0 - minWet0),
1422                    hMod,
1423                    halfHeight = (height - 1) * 0.5, i_half = 1.0 / halfHeight;
1424            double minHeightActual0 = minHeightActual;
1425            double maxHeightActual0 = maxHeightActual;
1426            yPos = startY;
1427            ps = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY;
1428            pc = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY;
1429
1430            for (int y = 0; y < height; y++, yPos += i_uh) {
1431                temp = Math.abs(yPos - halfHeight) * i_half;
1432                temp *= (2.4 - temp);
1433                temp = 2.2 - temp;
1434                for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
1435//                    heightData[x][y] = (h = (heightData[x][y] - minHeightActual) * heightDiff - 1.0);
1436//                    minHeightActual0 = Math.min(minHeightActual0, h);
1437//                    maxHeightActual0 = Math.max(maxHeightActual0, h);
1438                    h = heightData[x][y];
1439                    heightCodeData[x][y] = (t = codeHeight(h));
1440                    hMod = 1.0;
1441                    switch (t) {
1442                        case 0:
1443                        case 1:
1444                        case 2:
1445                        case 3:
1446                            h = 0.4;
1447                            hMod = 0.2;
1448                            break;
1449                        case 6:
1450                            h = -0.1 * (h - forestLower - 0.08);
1451                            break;
1452                        case 7:
1453                            h *= -0.25;
1454                            break;
1455                        case 8:
1456                            h *= -0.4;
1457                            break;
1458                        default:
1459                            h *= 0.05;
1460                    }
1461                    heatData[x][y] = (h = (((heatData[x][y] - minHeat0) * heatDiff * hMod) + h + 0.6) * temp);
1462                    if (fresh) {
1463                        ps = Math.min(ps, h); //minHeat0
1464                        pc = Math.max(pc, h); //maxHeat0
1465                    }
1466                }
1467            }
1468            if(fresh)
1469            {
1470                minHeat1 = ps;
1471                maxHeat1 = pc;
1472            }
1473            heatDiff = heatModifier / (maxHeat1 - minHeat1);
1474            qs = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY;
1475            qc = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY;
1476            ps = Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY;
1477            pc = Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY;
1478
1479
1480            for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
1481                for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
1482                    heatData[x][y] = (h = ((heatData[x][y] - minHeat1) * heatDiff));
1483                    moistureData[x][y] = (temp = (moistureData[x][y] - minWet0) * wetDiff);
1484                    if (fresh) {
1485                        qs = Math.min(qs, h);
1486                        qc = Math.max(qc, h);
1487                        ps = Math.min(ps, temp);
1488                        pc = Math.max(pc, temp);
1489                    }
1490                }
1491            }
1492            if(fresh)
1493            {
1494                minHeat = qs;
1495                maxHeat = qc;
1496                minWet = ps;
1497                maxWet = pc;
1498            }
1499            landData.refill(heightCodeData, 4, 999);
1500            /*
1501            if(generateRivers) {
1502                if (fresh) {
1503                    addRivers();
1504                    riverData.connect8way().thin().thin();
1505                    lakeData.connect8way().thin();
1506                    partialRiverData.remake(riverData);
1507                    partialLakeData.remake(lakeData);
1508                } else {
1509                    partialRiverData.remake(riverData);
1510                    partialLakeData.remake(lakeData);
1511                    int stx = (zoomStartX >> (zoom)) - (width >> 1),
1512                            sty = (zoomStartY >> (zoom)) - (height >> 1);
1513                    for (int i = 1; i <= zoom; i++) {
1514//                        int stx = (startCacheX.get(i) - startCacheX.get(i - 1)) << (i - 1),
1515//                                sty = (startCacheY.get(i) - startCacheY.get(i - 1)) << (i - 1);
1516                        if ((i & 3) == 3) {
1517                            partialRiverData.zoom(stx, sty).connect8way();
1518                            partialRiverData.or(workingData.remake(partialRiverData).fringe().quasiRandomRegion(0.4));
1519                            partialLakeData.zoom(stx, sty).connect8way();
1520                            partialLakeData.or(workingData.remake(partialLakeData).fringe().quasiRandomRegion(0.55));
1521                        } else {
1522                            partialRiverData.zoom(stx, sty).connect8way().thin();
1523                            partialRiverData.or(workingData.remake(partialRiverData).fringe().quasiRandomRegion(0.5));
1524                            partialLakeData.zoom(stx, sty).connect8way().thin();
1525                            partialLakeData.or(workingData.remake(partialLakeData).fringe().quasiRandomRegion(0.7));
1526                        }
1527                    }
1528                }
1529            }
1530            */
